title: Calculation of results for Pb-210 in water by proportional counter

author: Marko Štrok, Reaktorski center, Institut "Jožef Stefan"

segmentation: Hello, my name is Marco and in this part you will learn how to calculate results for the determination of lead to 10 in water samples measured by proportional counter.
As a result of measurements, we get better count rate in our sample and background.
Has led to 10 has been separated from other Indian clients.
Bait account rate in the sample could be related to lead to 10.
However, Bismuth 210 starts to grow after separation and reaches equilibrium with lead to 10 in approximately 30 days as shown on the figure.
We have to account for that when determining detection efficiency as well As for self absorption within the sample.
He
Sultzer fled to 10 activity concentration in water.
Samples can be calculated using this simple equation 1.
In the equation we have on top background, subtracted beta count rate, which we divide by the chemical recovery detection, efficiency and volume of the sampler.
Count rate is calculated with equation 2 by division of number of counts, that is, number of beta events recorded divided by measurement time.

Chemical recovery can be calculated grammatically as shown in equation 3 by multiplying of mass of lead sulfate at the end of separation with smaller mass of lead to 10 and dividing it by mass of edit let before separation multiplied by molar mass of lead sulfate.
Detection efficiency is based on the proportional counter used and used methodology to correct for Bismuth 210 in growth and self absorption.
We have to calculate measurement to certainty using can certainty propagation loss.

Each of the element in equation 1 used to calculate or measured as an uncertain T. Integration for first term in brackets is showing creative standard certainty of background subtracted, bit account rate, second term, relative standard, or certainty of chemical recovery.
Third, relative standard of certainty of detection, efficiency and last relative standard for certainty of volume of the sample.

Standard uncertainties of background subtracted count rates can be calculated using equations five and six were standard for certainty of the count rate is calculated as poison distribution as one divided by the square root of number of counts, as shown in equation 6.
Standard, the certainty of sample volume depends on used volume measuring cylinder.
When we report results, we usually multiply combined standard certainty by the coverage factor to get expanded.
The certainty as shown in equation 7.
Usually we take coverage factor of two, which represents that there is 95% probability that the true value lies within our measured value plus minus expenditure certainty.
Finally, we report our results as activity concentration plus minus expanded the certainty.
We also have to provide which courage factor we used.
